an8.80:0.3.eng: Grounds for Laziness and Arousing Energy

an8.80:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are eight grounds for laziness.

an8.80:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā kammaṃ kattabbaṃ hoti.
an8.80:1.3.eng: Firstly, a mendicant has some work to do.

an8.80:1.5.pli: ‘kammaṃ kho me kattabbaṃ bhavissati. Kammaṃ kho pana me karontassa kāyo kilamissati. Handāhaṃ nipajjāmī’ti.
an8.80:1.5.eng: ‘I have some work to do. But while doing it my body will get tired. I’d better have a lie down.’

an8.80:1.6.pli: So nipajjati, na vīriyaṃ ārabhati appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
an8.80:1.6.eng: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.

an8.80:1.7.eng: This is the first ground for laziness.

an8.80:2.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā kammaṃ kataṃ hoti.
an8.80:2.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has done some work.

an8.80:2.3.pli: ‘ahaṃ kho kammaṃ akāsiṃ. Kammaṃ kho pana me karontassa kāyo kilanto. Handāhaṃ nipajjāmī’ti.
an8.80:2.3.eng: ‘I’ve done some work. But while working my body got tired. I’d better have a lie down.’

an8.80:2.4.pli: So nipajjati, na vīriyaṃ ārabhati appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
an8.80:2.4.eng: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.

an8.80:2.5.eng: This is the second ground for laziness.

an8.80:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā maggo gantabbo hoti.
an8.80:3.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has to go on a journey.

an8.80:3.3.pli: ‘maggo me gantabbo bhavissati. Maggaṃ kho pana me gacchantassa kāyo kilamissati. Handāhaṃ nipajjāmī’ti.
an8.80:3.3.eng: ‘I have to go on a journey. But while walking my body will get tired. I’d better have a lie down.’

an8.80:3.4.pli: So nipajjati, na vīriyaṃ ārabhati appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
an8.80:3.4.eng: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.

an8.80:3.5.eng: This is the third ground for laziness.

an8.80:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā maggo gato hoti.
an8.80:4.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has gone on a journey.

an8.80:4.3.pli: ‘ahaṃ kho maggaṃ agamāsiṃ. Maggaṃ kho pana me gacchantassa kāyo kilanto. Handāhaṃ nipajjāmī’ti.
an8.80:4.3.eng: ‘I’ve gone on a journey. But while walking my body got tired. I’d better have a lie down.’

an8.80:4.4.pli: So nipajjati, na vīriyaṃ ārabhati appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
an8.80:4.4.eng: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.

an8.80:4.5.eng: This is the fourth ground for laziness.

an8.80:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā piṇḍāya caranto na labhati lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṃ pāripūriṃ.
an8.80:5.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has wandered for alms, but they didn’t get to fill up on as much food as they like, coarse or fine.

an8.80:5.3.pli: ‘ahaṃ kho gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā piṇḍāya caranto nālatthaṃ lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṃ pāripūriṃ. Tassa me kāyo kilanto akammañño. Handāhaṃ nipajjāmī’ti.
an8.80:5.3.eng: ‘I’ve wandered for alms, but I didn’t get to fill up on as much food as I like, coarse or fine. My body is tired and unfit for work. I’d better have a lie down.’

an8.80:5.4.eng: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy for achieving the unachieved, attaining the unattained, and realizing the unrealized.

an8.80:5.5.eng: This is the fifth ground for laziness.

an8.80:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā piṇḍāya caranto labhati lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṃ pāripūriṃ.
an8.80:6.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has wandered for alms, and they got to fill up on as much food as they like, coarse or fine.

an8.80:6.3.pli: ‘ahaṃ kho gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā piṇḍāya caranto alatthaṃ lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṃ pāripūriṃ. Tassa me kāyo garuko akammañño māsācitaṃ maññe. Handāhaṃ nipajjāmī’ti.
an8.80:6.3.eng: ‘I’ve wandered for alms, and I got to fill up on as much food as I like, coarse or fine. My body is heavy, unfit for work, like I’ve just eaten a load of beans. I’d better have a lie down.’

an8.80:6.4.eng: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy for achieving the unachieved, attaining the unattained, and realizing the unrealized.

an8.80:6.5.eng: This is the sixth ground for laziness.

an8.80:7.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno uppanno hoti appamattako ābādho.
an8.80:7.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant feels a little sick.

an8.80:7.3.pli: ‘uppanno kho me ayaṃ appamattako ābādho atthi kappo nipajjituṃ. Handāhaṃ nipajjāmī’ti.
an8.80:7.3.eng: ‘I feel a little sick. Lying down would be good for me. I’d better have a lie down.’

an8.80:7.4.eng: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy for achieving the unachieved, attaining the unattained, and realizing the unrealized.

an8.80:7.5.eng: This is the seventh ground for laziness.

an8.80:8.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu gilānā vuṭṭhito hoti aciravuṭṭhito gelaññā.
an8.80:8.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has recently recovered from illness.

an8.80:8.3.pli: ‘ahaṃ kho gilānā vuṭṭhito aciravuṭṭhito gelaññā. Tassa me kāyo dubbalo akammañño. Handāhaṃ nipajjāmī’ti.
an8.80:8.3.eng: ‘I’ve recently recovered from illness. My body is weak and unfit for work. I’d better have a lie down.’

an8.80:8.4.pli: So nipajjati, na vīriyaṃ ārabhati appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
an8.80:8.4.eng: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.

an8.80:8.5.eng: This is the eighth ground for laziness.

an8.80:8.6.eng: These are the eight grounds for laziness.

an8.80:9.1.eng: There are eight grounds for arousing energy.

an8.80:9.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā kammaṃ kattabbaṃ hoti.
an8.80:9.3.eng: Firstly, a mendicant has some work to do.

an8.80:9.5.pli: ‘kammaṃ kho me kattabbaṃ bhavissati. Kammaṃ kho mayā karontena na sukaraṃ buddhānaṃ sāsanaṃ manasi kātuṃ. Handāhaṃ paṭikacceva vīriyaṃ ārabhāmi appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāyā’ti.
an8.80:9.5.eng: ‘I have some work to do. While working it’s not easy to focus on the instructions of the Buddhas. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.’

an8.80:9.6.pli: So vīriyaṃ ārabhati appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
an8.80:9.6.eng: They rouse energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.

an8.80:9.7.eng: This is the first ground for arousing energy.

an8.80:10.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā kammaṃ kataṃ hoti.
an8.80:10.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has done some work.

an8.80:10.3.pli: ‘ahaṃ kho kammaṃ akāsiṃ. Kammaṃ kho panāhaṃ karonto nāsakkhiṃ buddhānaṃ sāsanaṃ manasi kātuṃ. Handāhaṃ vīriyaṃ ārabhāmi appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāyā’ti.
an8.80:10.3.eng: ‘I’ve done some work. While I was working I wasn’t able to focus on the instructions of the Buddhas. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.’

an8.80:10.5.eng: This is the second ground for arousing energy.

an8.80:11.3.pli: maggo kho me gantabbo bhavissati. Maggaṃ kho pana me gacchantena na sukaraṃ buddhānaṃ sāsanaṃ manasi kātuṃ. Handāhaṃ vīriyaṃ …pe…
an8.80:11.3.eng: ‘I have to go on a journey. While walking it’s not easy to focus on the instructions of the Buddhas. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy …’ …

an8.80:11.4.eng: This is the third ground for arousing energy.

an8.80:12.4.eng: This is the fourth ground for arousing energy.

an8.80:13.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has wandered for alms, but they didn’t get to fill up on as much food as they like, coarse or fine.

an8.80:13.3.eng: ‘I’ve wandered for alms, but I didn’t get to fill up on as much food as I like, rough or fine. My body is light and fit for work. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy …’ …

an8.80:13.4.eng: This is the fifth ground for arousing energy.

an8.80:14.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā piṇḍāya caranto labhati lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṃ pāripūriṃ.
an8.80:14.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has wandered for alms, and they got to fill up on as much food as they like, coarse or fine.

an8.80:14.3.pli: ahaṃ kho gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā piṇḍāya caranto alatthaṃ lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṃ pāripūriṃ. Tassa me kāyo balavā kammañño. Handāhaṃ vīriyaṃ ārabhāmi …pe…
an8.80:14.3.eng: ‘I’ve wandered for alms, and I got to fill up on as much food as I like, coarse or fine. My body is strong and fit for work. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy …’ …

an8.80:14.4.eng: This is the sixth ground for arousing energy.

an8.80:15.3.pli: uppanno kho me ayaṃ appamattako ābādho. Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ vijjati yaṃ me ābādho pavaḍḍheyya. Handāhaṃ paṭikacceva vīriyaṃ ārabhāmi …pe…
an8.80:15.3.eng: ‘I feel a little sick. It’s possible this illness will worsen. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy …’ …

an8.80:15.4.eng: This is the seventh ground for arousing energy.

an8.80:16.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has recently recovered from illness.

an8.80:16.3.pli: ‘ahaṃ kho gilānā vuṭṭhito aciravuṭṭhito gelaññā. Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ vijjati yaṃ me ābādho paccudāvatteyya. Handāhaṃ paṭikacceva vīriyaṃ ārabhāmi appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāyā’ti.
an8.80:16.3.eng: ‘I’ve recently recovered from illness. It’s possible the illness will come back. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.’

an8.80:16.4.pli: So vīriyaṃ ārabhati appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
an8.80:16.4.eng: They rouse energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.

an8.80:16.5.eng: This is the eighth ground for arousing energy.

an8.81:1.1.pli: “Satisampajaññe, bhikkhave, asati satisampajaññavipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti hirottappaṃ.
an8.81:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when there is no mindfulness and situational awareness, one who lacks mindfulness and situational awareness has destroyed a vital condition for conscience and prudence.

an8.81:1.2.pli: Hirottappe asati hirottappavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti indriyasaṃvaro.
an8.81:1.2.eng: When there is no conscience and prudence, one who lacks conscience and prudence has destroyed a vital condition for sense restraint.

an8.81:1.3.pli: Indriyasaṃvare asati indriyasaṃvaravipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti sīlaṃ.
an8.81:1.3.eng: When there is no sense restraint, one who lacks sense restraint has destroyed a vital condition for ethical conduct.

an8.81:1.4.pli: Sīle asati sīlavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti sammāsamādhi.
an8.81:1.4.eng: When there is no ethical conduct, one who lacks ethics has destroyed a vital condition for right immersion.

an8.81:1.5.pli: Sammāsamādhimhi asati sammāsamādhivipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ.
an8.81:1.5.eng: When there is no right immersion, one who lacks right immersion has destroyed a vital condition for true knowledge and vision.

an8.81:1.6.pli: Yathābhūtañāṇadassane asati yathābhūtañāṇadassanavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti nibbidāvirāgo.
an8.81:1.6.eng: When there is no true knowledge and vision, one who lacks true knowledge and vision has destroyed a vital condition for disillusionment and dispassion.

an8.81:1.7.pli: Nibbidāvirāge asati nibbidāvirāgavipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ.
an8.81:1.7.eng: When there is no disillusionment and dispassion, one who lacks disillusionment and dispassion has destroyed a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.

an8.81:1.8.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, rukkho sākhāpalāsavipanno. Tassa papaṭikāpi na pāripūriṃ gacchati, tacopi … pheggupi … sāropi na pāripūriṃ gacchati.
an8.81:1.8.eng: Suppose there was a tree that lacked branches and foliage. Its shoots, bark, softwood, and heartwood would not grow to fullness.

an8.81:1.9.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, satisampajaññe asati satisampajaññavipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti hirottappaṃ;
an8.81:1.9.eng: In the same way, when there is no mindfulness and situational awareness, one who lacks mindfulness and situational awareness has destroyed a vital condition for conscience and prudence.

an8.81:1.10.eng: When there is no conscience and prudence …

an8.81:1.11.eng: One who lacks disillusionment and dispassion has destroyed a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.

an8.81:2.1.pli: Satisampajaññe, bhikkhave, sati satisampajaññasampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti hirottappaṃ.
an8.81:2.1.eng: When there is mindfulness and situational awareness, one who has fulfilled mindfulness and situational awareness has fulfilled a vital condition for conscience and prudence.

an8.81:2.2.pli: Hirottappe sati hirottappasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti indriyasaṃvaro.
an8.81:2.2.eng: When there is conscience and prudence, one who has fulfilled conscience and prudence has fulfilled a vital condition for sense restraint.

an8.81:2.3.pli: Indriyasaṃvare sati indriyasaṃvarasampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti sīlaṃ.
an8.81:2.3.eng: When there is sense restraint, one who has fulfilled sense restraint has fulfilled a vital condition for ethical conduct.

an8.81:2.4.pli: Sīle sati sīlasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti sammāsamādhi.
an8.81:2.4.eng: When there is ethical conduct, one who has fulfilled ethical conduct has fulfilled a vital condition for right immersion.

an8.81:2.5.pli: Sammāsamādhimhi sati sammāsamādhisampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ.
an8.81:2.5.eng: When there is right immersion, one who has fulfilled right immersion has fulfilled a vital condition for true knowledge and vision.

an8.81:2.6.pli: Yathābhūtañāṇadassane sati yathābhūtañāṇadassanasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti nibbidāvirāgo.
an8.81:2.6.eng: When there is true knowledge and vision, one who has fulfilled true knowledge and vision has fulfilled a vital condition for disillusionment and dispassion.

an8.81:2.7.pli: Nibbidāvirāge sati nibbidāvirāgasampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ.
an8.81:2.7.eng: When there is disillusionment and dispassion, one who has fulfilled disillusionment and dispassion has fulfilled a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.

an8.81:2.8.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, rukkho sākhāpalāsasampanno. Tassa papaṭikāpi pāripūriṃ gacchati, tacopi … pheggupi … sāropi pāripūriṃ gacchati.
an8.81:2.8.eng: Suppose there was a tree that was complete with branches and foliage. Its shoots, bark, softwood, and heartwood would grow to fullness.

an8.81:2.9.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, satisampajaññe sati satisampajaññasampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti hirottappaṃ;
an8.81:2.9.eng: In the same way, when there is mindfulness and situational awareness, one who has fulfilled mindfulness and situational awareness has fulfilled a vital condition for conscience and prudence.

an8.81:2.10.eng: When there is conscience and prudence …

an8.81:2.11.eng: One who has fulfilled disillusionment and dispassion has fulfilled a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.”

an8.82:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā puṇṇiyo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā puṇṇiyo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an8.82:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Puṇṇiya went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an8.82:1.2.pli: “ko nu kho, bhante, hetu ko paccayo yena appekadā tathāgataṃ dhammadesanā paṭibhāti, appekadā na paṭibhātī”ti?
an8.82:1.2.eng: “Sir, what is the cause, what is the reason why sometimes the Realized One feels inspired to teach, and other times not?”

an8.82:1.3.pli: “Saddho ca, puṇṇiya, bhikkhu hoti, no cupasaṅkamitā;
an8.82:1.3.eng: “Puṇṇiya, when a mendicant has faith but doesn’t approach,

an8.82:1.4.eng: the Realized One doesn’t feel inspired to teach.

an8.82:1.5.pli: Yato ca kho, puṇṇiya, bhikkhu saddho ca hoti, upasaṅkamitā ca;
an8.82:1.5.eng: But when a mendicant has faith and approaches,

an8.82:1.6.eng: the Realized One feels inspired to teach.

an8.82:1.7.pli: Saddho ca, puṇṇiya, bhikkhu hoti, upasaṅkamitā ca, no ca payirupāsitā …pe…
an8.82:1.7.eng: When a mendicant has faith and approaches, but doesn’t pay homage …

an8.82:1.8.eng: they pay homage, but don’t ask questions …

an8.82:1.9.pli: paripucchitā ca, no ca ohitasoto dhammaṃ suṇāti …
an8.82:1.9.eng: they ask questions, but don’t actively listen to the teaching …

an8.82:1.10.pli: ohitasoto ca dhammaṃ suṇāti, no ca sutvā dhammaṃ dhāreti …
an8.82:1.10.eng: they actively listen to the teaching, but don’t remember the teaching they’ve heard …

an8.82:1.11.pli: sutvā ca dhammaṃ dhāreti, no ca dhātānaṃ dhammānaṃ atthaṃ upaparikkhati …
an8.82:1.11.eng: they remember the teaching they’ve heard, but don’t examine the meaning of the teachings they’ve remembered …

an8.82:1.12.pli: dhātānañca dhammānaṃ atthaṃ upaparikkhati, no ca atthamaññāya dhammamaññāya dhammānudhammappaṭipanno hoti.
an8.82:1.12.eng: they examine the meaning of the teachings they’ve remembered, but, not having understood the meaning and the teaching, they don’t practice in line with the principle of the teaching.

an8.82:1.13.eng: The Realized One doesn’t feel inspired to teach.

an8.82:2.1.pli: Yato ca kho, puṇṇiya, bhikkhu saddho ca hoti, upasaṅkamitā ca, payirupāsitā ca, paripucchitā ca, ohitasoto ca dhammaṃ suṇāti, sutvā ca dhammaṃ dhāreti, dhātānañca dhammānaṃ atthaṃ upaparikkhati, atthamaññāya dhammamaññāya dhammānudhammappaṭipanno ca hoti;
an8.82:2.1.eng: But when a mendicant has faith, approaches, pays homage, asks questions, actively listens to the teachings, remembers the teachings, examines the meaning, and practices in line with the principle of the teaching,

an8.82:2.2.eng: the Realized One feels inspired to teach.

an8.82:2.3.pli: Imehi kho, puṇṇiya, aṭṭhahi dhammehi samannāgatā ekantapaṭibhānā tathāgataṃ dhammadesanā hotī”ti.
an8.82:2.3.eng: When someone possesses these eight qualities, the Realized One feels totally inspired to teach.”

an8.83:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, if wanderers of other religions were to ask:

an8.83:1.2.pli: ‘kiṃmūlakā, āvuso, sabbe dhammā, kiṃsambhavā sabbe dhammā, kiṃsamudayā sabbe dhammā, kiṃsamosaraṇā sabbe dhammā, kiṃpamukhā sabbe dhammā, kiṃadhipateyyā sabbe dhammā, kiṃuttarā sabbe dhammā, kiṃsārā sabbe dhammā’ti, evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, bhikkhave, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ kinti byākareyyāthā”ti?
an8.83:1.2.eng: ‘Reverends, all things have what as their root? What produces them? What is their origin? What is their meeting place? What is their chief? What is their ruler? What is their overseer? What is their core?’ How would you answer them?”

an8.83:1.3.pli: “Bhagavaṃmūlakā no, bhante, dhammā, bhagavaṃnettikā bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇā. Sādhu, bhante, bhagavantaṃyeva paṭibhātu etassa bhāsitassa attho. Bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
an8.83:1.3.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge. Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

an8.83:2.1.eng: “Well then, mendicants, I will teach it.

an8.83:2.2.pli: Taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
an8.83:2.2.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

an8.83:2.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

an8.83:2.5.eng: “Mendicants, if wanderers of other religions were to ask:

an8.83:2.6.pli: ‘kiṃmūlakā, āvuso, sabbe dhammā, kiṃsambhavā sabbe dhammā, kiṃsamudayā sabbe dhammā, kiṃsamosaraṇā sabbe dhammā, kiṃpamukhā sabbe dhammā, kiṃadhipateyyā sabbe dhammā, kiṃuttarā sabbe dhammā, kiṃsārā sabbe dhammā’ti,
an8.83:2.6.eng: ‘Reverends, all things have what as their root? What produces them? What is their origin? What is their meeting place? What is their chief? What is their ruler? What is their overseer? What is their core?’

an8.83:2.7.pli: evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, bhikkhave, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ evaṃ byākareyyātha:

an8.83:2.8.pli: ‘chandamūlakā, āvuso, sabbe dhammā, manasikārasambhavā sabbe dhammā, phassasamudayā sabbe dhammā, vedanāsamosaraṇā sabbe dhammā, samādhippamukhā sabbe dhammā, satādhipateyyā sabbe dhammā, paññuttarā sabbe dhammā, vimuttisārā sabbe dhammā’ti,
an8.83:2.8.eng: ‘Reverends, all things are rooted in desire. They are produced by application of mind. Contact is their origin. Feeling is their meeting place. Immersion is their chief. Mindfulness is their ruler. Wisdom is their overseer. Freedom is their core.’

an8.83:2.9.pli: evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, bhikkhave, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ evaṃ byākareyyāthā”ti.
an8.83:2.9.eng: When questioned by wanderers of other religions, that’s how you should answer them.”

an8.84:1.1.pli: “Aṭṭhahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato mahācoro khippaṃ pariyāpajjati, na ciraṭṭhitiko hoti.
an8.84:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a master thief with eight factors is soon executed, and doesn’t have long to live.

an8.84:1.3.pli: Appaharantassa paharati, anavasesaṃ ādiyati, itthiṃ hanati, kumāriṃ dūseti, pabbajitaṃ vilumpati, rājakosaṃ vilumpati, accāsanne kammaṃ karoti, na ca nidhānakusalo hoti.
an8.84:1.3.eng: He attacks unprovoked. He steals everything without exception. He kills a woman. He rapes a girl. He robs a monk. He robs the royal treasury. He works close to home. He’s not skilled at hiding his booty.

an8.84:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭhahaṅgehi samannāgato mahācoro khippaṃ pariyāpajjati, na ciraṭṭhitiko hoti.
an8.84:1.4.eng: A master thief with these eight factors is soon executed, and doesn’t have long to live.

an8.84:2.1.pli: Aṭṭhahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato mahācoro na khippaṃ pariyāpajjati, ciraṭṭhitiko hoti.
an8.84:2.1.eng: A master thief with eight factors is not soon executed, and lives long.

an8.84:2.3.pli: Na appaharantassa paharati, na anavasesaṃ ādiyati, na itthiṃ hanati, na kumāriṃ dūseti, na pabbajitaṃ vilumpati, na rājakosaṃ vilumpati, na accāsanne kammaṃ karoti, nidhānakusalo ca hoti.
an8.84:2.3.eng: He doesn’t attack unprovoked. He doesn’t steal everything without exception. He doesn’t kill a woman. He doesn’t rape a girl. He doesn’t rob a monk. He doesn’t rob the royal treasury. He doesn’t work close to home. He’s skilled at hiding his booty.

an8.84:2.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭhahaṅgehi samannāgato mahācoro na khippaṃ pariyāpajjati, ciraṭṭhitiko hotī”ti.
an8.84:2.4.eng: A master thief with these eight factors is not soon executed, and lives long.”

an8.85:1.1.eng: “‘Ascetic’ is a term for the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.

an8.85:1.8.eng: and ‘Freed’ are terms for the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.

an8.85:2.1.eng: The supreme should be attained by an ascetic,

an8.85:2.2.eng: a brahmin who has lived the life;

an8.85:2.3.eng: it should be attained by a knowledge master,

an8.85:3.1.eng: The supreme should be attained by the unstained,

an8.85:3.3.eng: it should be attained by a knower,

an8.85:4.2.eng: Released, I release others from their chains.

an8.85:4.3.eng: I am a dragon completely tamed,
